Legal_Issue: Can panel members appointed under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act be named as respondents in a judicial review?
Governing_Law: Section 35(6) of the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act
Rule 1602(3) of the Federal Court Rules
Application_Facts: Sunshine Village Corporation challenged the appointment of an environmental assessment panel; panel members argued they were not 'interested parties' and were shielded by s. 35(6).
Decision_Outcome: The court declined to remove the panel members as respondents, allowing them to remain in the judicial review process.
Court_Ruling: Panel members remained as respondents; further motions scheduled for June 1-2, 1995.
Defendant_Behavior: Panel members moved to be struck as respondents, citing immunity under s. 35(6).
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged invalidity of panel members' appointment
Legal_Standard: Interpretation of 'interested person' under Rule 1602(3); scope of immunity under s. 35(6)
Assessment_Factor: Necessity of naming panel members for injunctive relief
Procedural_Issue: Motions to strike panel members as respondents
Application_Basis: Challenge to validity of panel appointment despite statutory immunity
Outcome: Panel members retained as respondents; case proceedings continued.
Cause_Description: Sunshine Village Corporation challenged the appointment of an environmental assessment panel by applying for judicial review.
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether panel members can be named as respondents under Federal Court Rules
Decision_Rationale: Naming panel members necessary for injunctive remedy; s. 35(6) does not bar challenge to appointment validity
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of respondent eligibility under Rule 1602(3); immunity under s. 35(6)
